hey guys,

After photographing a couple  of my latest acquisitions:

http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/photos/ko_kinko_front_small.JPG

I got some complaints that this looked too "milky" (funny about that 
because I was using the
ol' milkjug diffuser :-) )

These next couple of pics were taken using the traditional skim skim 
lighting that I normally use
on tsuba (see menuki3 and menuki4 in the yahoo photo album below:)

http://f2.pg.photos.yahoo.com/ph/rkgatteleport/lst?.dir=/menuki_test&.view=t

This still had the highlights kind of "blown out" so I then tried a 
technique they had described in that
color, light and magic book I've been studyin' - namely, putting a gobo 
between the light and the menuki.
since this renders the piece very dark, I had to up the exposure by a 
couple of stops to compensate.  Note
that I didn't get them quite the right size and that you see a little 
blue from the painters tape I use to hold
all this stuff up, but still...)  These can be seen in menuki3_gobo and 
menuki4_gobo  I suspect
I could darken up the background and improve things more, but...

I also tried this with another recent acquistion using the same 
nomenclature (see menuki1 & menuki2 in this
same directory).  Here you can see that the gold doesn't get as "washed 
out".

So what do you guys think?  Which method looks better?

In case you're bored, you can also check out my other photo directories 
here - the pointer to some recent pics of
my Yamato shizu katana  is:

http://tinyurl.com/ot2c

Obviously I did this during the day and need some more background to 
hide material (and a stronger spotlight and...),
but still...

And finally, I've turned to the dark side and have a Canon 10D coming, 
so the camera that took those pics above
is for sale (canon G2 with a pile of interesting accessories (filters, 
filter adapters, yada yada) - contact me privately
if interested (just thought I'd ask before throwing it up on ebay...).

P.S.  Like the sword holder?  if anybody has a line on some 2" square 
nylon, delrin, or some sort of uhmw pe plastic
rod that is black, I'd love to hear about it...
